questions.text: A 23-year-old came to the surgery OPD with the complaint of a Lumpy Breast. On examination firm, easily movable mass is noted on the breast. History of waxing and waning with the menstrual cycle is present. No other significant history is given by the patient. An Ultrasound breast was done. The most appropriate management of the lesion measuring ~2*2cm is:

options.label: D
options.text: Tru-cut Biopsy to rule out cancer

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reassurance The history, examination, and ultrasound point to the diagnosis of Fibroadenoma . Fibroadenoma in a young patient with no other history is best managed with reassurance . On USG fibroadenomas have smooth contours, round or oval shapes, weak internal echoes, and well-defined anterior and posterior margins. With short-term follow-up, a significant percentage of fibroadenomas decrease in size and are no longer palpable. Only observation & reassurance is required . Women should be counselled that the options for treatment include surgical removal, cryoablation, vacuum-assisted biopsy, or observation.

Highyeild:

Fibroadenoma is the most common benign tumour of the female breast that is composed of both fibrous and glandular tissue . It is most commonly seen in young women between the ages of 15 to 30 years and is caused by increased sensitivity of focal areas of breast tissue to estrogen. Fibroadenoma is commonly known as " breast mouse "

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Surgical Excision is done for fibroadenomas which are Symptomatic, growing rapidly, or causing cosmetic problems. Option: B. Cryoablation, RFA, Vacuum Assisted Biopsy Systems are good surgical modalities, useful in smaller lesions, but surgical treatment is not needed in this patient. Option: D. Biopsy of a fibroadenoma is only done in older patients or with patients with a family history of breast cancer.

Extraedge:

Mammography findings Popcorn calcification - fibroadenoma. Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification - traumatic fat necrosis. Broken-needle type of calcification - duct ectasia. Tea-cup calcification - fibrocystic disease.

questions.text: In a patient who presented with a slow-growing lump in her breast, a biopsy was considered, and the histopathological examination revealed Fibroadenoma. Which of the following are NOT the grounds for surgical treatment in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multiple Fibroadenoma Fibroadenoma is a benign condition of the breast. Even in a patient with histopathological confirmation of fibroadenoma, the patient can be reassured and surgery can be avoided. Multiple fibroadenoma s may occur in younger women & are generally self-limiting and resolve on their own. The reason for surgery includes the: Giant Fibroadenoma Juvenile Fibroadenoma Symptomatic Fibroadenoma bothering the patient Cosmetic Concern Growth in size Family History of Breast Cancer

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Giant Fibroadenoma is a term applied to a fibroadenoma that attains an unusually large size (typically >5 cm). Surgery is curative. Option: B. Juvenile Fibroadenoma refers to a large fibroadenoma that occasionally occurs in adolescents and young adults and histologically is more cellular than the usual fibroadenoma. Surgery is curative. Option: C. Cosmetic concern is also associated with some Fibroadenomas. Surgical Excision is done if the patient expressly desires the lump to be removed.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a lumpy swelling on her breast, which is tender & erythematous. She started nursing her newborn a few weeks back. What is the most appropriate treatment protocol for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Excision of the entire Subareolar Duct Complex

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antibiotics & Needle Aspiration The given scenario is that of mastitis developing into a Breast abscess. Breast Abscesses are best managed with antibiotics and repeated aspiration of the abscess, usually ultrasound-guided aspiration.

Highyeild:

Breast abscess Breast abscesses are commonly caused by staphylococcal infections . They are characterized by symptoms such as tenderness at a specific point, redness, and fever. These abscesses are often related to lactation and can occur during the first few weeks of breastfeeding. The transmission of S. aureus occurs through the neonate's suckling.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Breast Abscesses have a They are not cystic lesions. Option: B. Surgical incision drainage is reserved for abscesses that do not resolve after aspiration and treatment with antibiotics. In these rare cases, a biopsy is taken to rule out Inflammatory Cancer. Option: D . Only repeated infections are treated with excision of the entire subareolar duct complex after the acute infection has resolved completely, & under IV antibiotic coverage.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has started noticing a Lump in her Right breast after an Injury. She is unsure if the lump was present before the incident. On examination, the palpable mass of 2*3cm was noted. Mammography was advised for her. What is the next course in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tru-Cut biopsy Fat necrosis can mimic cancer on examination & mammography by producing a palpable mass or density that may contain calcifications. It may even have skin tethering and nipple retraction. Fat necrosis may follow an episode of trauma to the breast. Histologically, fat necrosis is composed of lipid-laden macrophages, scar tissue, and chronic inflammatory cells. This lesion has no malignant potential.

Highyeild:

Mammography findings Popcorn calcification - fibroadenoma. Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification - traumatic fat necrosis. Broken-needle type of calcification - duct ectasia. Tea-cup calcification - fibrocystic disease.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. There is a suspicion of Breast Cancer, so a biopsy is required for diagnosis. FNAC is not useful. Option: C. Surgical options are considered according to the diagnosis of this patient. Option: D. 6 monthly monitoring is done for BIRADS 3 lesions, which are probably benign . Whereas, Fat necrosis can mimic cancer mammography, so a Biopsy is required for confirmation.

Extraedge:

Mammography findings Popcorn calcification - fibroadenoma. Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification - traumatic fat necrosis. Broken-needle type of calcification - duct ectasia. Tea-cup calcification - fibrocystic disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman, the post-op case of T2/N0/M0 Breast Cancer, which was ER +ve, PR +ve, and Her-2-neu -ve, managed with Mastectomy. The Recurrence Score on molecular tests was low. What will be the protocol for Follow-up in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Yearly Mammography. In a Post-Op patient of Breast Cancer, there is further management with Radiotherapy, Chemotherapy, or Hormonal treatment, depending on a case-to-case basis. Generally, after the completion of treatment, patients with breast cancer are to be followed up with yearly or 2-yearly mammography of the treated and contralateral breast.

Highyeild:

Table - 1 - Comparison of Mammography, breast ultrasound, MRI, PET scan and biopsy Investigation Purpose Advantage Disadvantage Mammography Detecting breast masses High sensitivity and specificity, non-invasive, widely available Radiation exposure, discomfort during compression, false positive results Breast ultrasound Differentiating between solid and cystic masses Non-invasive, no radiation exposure, can distinguish between fluid-filled cysts and solid masses Operator-dependent, limited ability to differentiate between benign and malignant masses MRI Detecting breast cancer in high- risk women and assessing extent of disease High sensitivity, no radiation exposure, can detect multiple sites of cancer, can evaluate implant integrity High cost, limited availability, false positive results PET scan Detecting distant metastases High sensitivity for detecting distant metastases, can detect metastases before they become clinically apparent Limited role in primary breast cancer evaluation, high cost, false positive results Biopsy Confirming diagnosis and determining tumor characteristics Accurate diagnosis, determining hormone receptor status and HER2 status Invasive, potential for complications such as bleeding or infection, may not be feasible for all patients or lesions.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. No routine role for repeated measurements of tumour markers Option: C. No routine role for imaging other than mammography. Option: D. The patient is returned early to the care of the general practitioner with fast-track access back to the breast clinic if suspicious symptoms appear.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with ER+/PR+ Breast Cancer underwent surgery for the same & was started on chemotherapy as well. Which treatment should also be added to this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Tamoxifen followed by Letrozole, in a 10 years span.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Letrozole * 5years Selective aromatase inhibitors , like Letrozole , anastrozole and exemestane are restricted for use in postmenopausal women . Oral aromatase inhibitors for postmenopausal women are now used for the treatment of all stages of the disease and have been shown to be superior to tamoxifen. Pre- or perimenopausal women , who have received 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen, should be offered a 10-year total duration of tamoxifen. Postmenopausal women who have received 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen, should be offered the choice of continuing tamoxifen or switching to aromatase inhibitors for 10 years of total adjuvant endocrine therapy. Selective aromatase inhibitors are unable to suppress ovarian function completely in a premenopausal or perimenopausal woman and are restricted for use in postmenopausal women.

Highyeild:

Hormone therapy is used in breast cancer and involves the use of selective oestrogen receptor modulators such as tamoxifen, and aromatase inhibitors including anastrozole, letrozole and exemestane. Tamoxifen is used only in premenopausal patients for a period of 5 years in low-risk patients and 10 years in high-risk patients with node-positive disease, tumour size >5 cm or lymphovascular invasion . Aromatase inhibitors are preferred in postmenopausal women and have shown better outcomes in terms of relapse-free survival and overall survival compared to tamoxifen in an adjuvant setting.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Tamoxifen is now given for a duration of 10 years Option: C. Tamoxifen is not started in a post-menopausal woman, as aromatase inhibitors have better results and a different side effect profile. Option: D. Only those post-menopausal women who have already received 5 years of adjuvant tamoxifen, should be offered the choice of continuing tamoxifen or switching to an AI, for the rest of the therapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient started on chemotherapy and endocrinal therapy for Breast cancer can have the following side-effects to the drugs given. Which of the following is not a match?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A Cytoxin or cyclophosphamide , the most characteristic S/E is hemorrhagic cystitis. Bone loss is seen with aromatase inhibitors. Drugs given to a patient for chemotherapy, independent of age or tumour characteristics, will include - a taxane or anthracycline regimen. Whereas, tamoxifen, is preferred as a part of hormonal therapy.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. With tamoxifen , the most common symptom is hot flashes. Option: C. Anthracyclines are known to be cardiotoxic and cause cardiomyopathy Option: D. Taxanes are associated with the potential permanent toxic effect of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: For a 48-year-old patient, diagnosed with Breast Cancer, T3/N0/M0, with ER (+)/PR (+)/Her-2-neu (-), what is the best course of treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Neo-Adjuvant Chemotherapy f/b Modified Radical Mastectomy.

options.label: B
options.text: Neo-Adjuvant Chemotherapy f/b Breast-conserving surgery with Radiotherapy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Neo-Adjuvant Chemotherapy f/b Breast-conserving surgery with Radiotherapy.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neo-Adjuvant Chemotherapy f/b Breast-conserving surgery with Radiotherapy. Neo -Adjuvant Chemotherapy administration before surgery may decrease the tumour size sufficiently to permit breast-conserving surgery in patients who would not otherwise appear to be good candidates. T3 N0 M0 is classified as Stage IIB. Radiotherapy is given to all patients who undergo Breast-Conserving Surgery. Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy decreases tumour size and allows Breast-Conserving Surgery. radiotherapy is given to all patients who undergo Breast-Conserving Surgery .

Highyeild:

NACT (neoadjuvant chemotherapy) is used for the following indications: Locally advanced breast cancer with T3, T4/N2, and N3 disease to shrink the tumour. Early breast cancer in select cases to make it easier to perform breast conservation surgery (BCS). HER2/neu-positive tumours and triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). Premenopausal women (age <50 years). Patients with axillary node metastasis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. MRM is only considered in the case of Locally Advanced Breast Cancer. Option: C. Patient doesn’t fulfil the criteria for radiotherapy. Option: D. Breast Conserving Surgery cannot be done in this patient as the size of the tumour will make it difficult to preserve breast tissue.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman, diagnosed with breast cancer, was planned with Neoadjuvant chemotherapy, Mastectomy, and Radiation therapy, with endocrine therapy with Tamoxifen and Trastuzumab. Which of the following could be the patient’s profile? Tumour size 5cm with no lymph nodes involvement Chest wall involvement Tumour size 4cm, axillary lymph node (Movable ipsilateral level I, II) involvement Peau d'orange Internal mammary lymph nodes involvement Supraclavicular lymph node involvement Lumbar vertebrae metastasis Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 4, 5, 6 Locally advanced breast cancer includes patients with (stages IIB, IIIA, and IIIB disease).: Large primary tumour (>5 cm), TumorTumours involving the chest wall, Skin involvement, ulceration or satellite skin nodules, Inflammatory carcinoma, Bulky or fixed axillary nodes, and Clinically apparent internal mammary or supraclavicular nodal involvement Neoadjuvant chemotherapy, Mastectomy, and Radiation therapy, with endocrine therapy with Tamoxifen and Trastuzumab, is a treatment plan for a patient with Locally Advanced Breast Cancer or Inflammatory Breast Cancer. Statement 1 . Tumour Size 5cm with no Lymph Nodes Involvement is a Grade IIB Cancer. Which can be treated with Breast Conservative Surgery . Statement 2 . Chest wall Involvement is a part of Locally Advanced Breast Cancer Statement 3. Tumour Size 4cm, axillary lymph node (Movable ipsilateral Level I, II) involvement is a tumour which can be treated with more conservative options like Breast Conservative Surgery, and Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy is not needed in this case. Statement 4 . Peau d'orange is a part of Locally Advanced Breast Cancer Statement 5 . Internal mammary lymph nodes involvement is a part of Locally Advanced Breast Cancer Statement 6. Supraclavicular lymph node involvement is a part of Locally Advanced Breast Cancer Statement 7. Lumbar Vertebrae Metastasis is a disease which can only be given palliative care .

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient with a large, massive, tumour with an unevenly bosselated surface, of size 6cm, was being evaluated for further management, and on HPE she had cellular atypia, a high number of mitoses, and stromal overgrowth. Which is the most suitable surgery for this?

options.label: C
options.text: Wide local Excision with systemic therapy

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mastectomy f/b Radiotherapy The given scenario is of Malignant Phyllodes Tumor It is a benign tumour, previously sometimes known as Cystosarcoma phyllodes. Usually occurs in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Presents as a large , sometimes massive, tumour with an unevenly bosselated surface. Different entities called Benign phyllodes tumours, Borderline phyllodes tumours, & Malignant phyllodes tumours are known. Treatment of Malignant Disease: Complete surgical excision of the entire tumour with a margin of normal tissue is advised In a large tumour total mastectomy is recommended Radiation therapy is recommended if- Margins are concerning or close, if the tumour involves the fascia or chest wall, if the tumour is very large (>5 cm), or If else only wide local excision is performed. Mastectomy f/b Adjuvant Radiotherapy is the best Treatment for this Patient.

Highyeild:

Phyllodes tumour is a rare (< 1% of all breast tumours), large(>3cm), rapidly growing, discrete and firm painless breast lump. They are usually benign, but most of them have malignant potential. They originate from the hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. Clinical features: Large breast with the unevenly bosselated surface. Pressure necrosis may cause skin ulceration. They are mobile on the chest wall Mostly seen in 40–50 years (premenopausal) age. Phyllodes tumours are fibroepithelial tumours composed of epithelial and stromal components. Biopsy shows a leaf-like appearance under the microscope.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Wide Local Excision in a large tumour is not sufficient and must be accompanied by Radiotherapy. Option: B . Mastectomy is done in this case, with Adjuvant Radiotherapy as Size >5cm Option: C . Systemic therapy is not successful in Phyllodes.

questions.text: In a patient, desires to have Breast Conserving Surgery as a part of Breast Cancer Treatment, all of the following can be a reason to defer this patient, Except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bilateral Breast Cancer Breast-Conserving Surgery is currently the standard treatment for women with stage 0, I, or II invasive breast cancer. It involves resection of the primary breast cancer with a margin of normal-appearing breast tissue, adjuvant radiation therapy, and assessment of regional lymph node status.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Pregnancy is a contraindication to Radiotherapy, so Breast Conserving Surgery cannot be done Option: B. Multicentric Disease is difficult to treat with Breast-Conserving Surgery. Women with large cancers that occupy the subareolar and central portions of the breast and women with multicentric primary cancers undergo mastectomy. Option: D. Locally Advanced Disease has to be treated with Neoadjuvant chemotherapy, MRM, and then further management depending upon the case.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient underwent a Modified Radical Mastectomy for the treatment of Breast Cancer. What about the complications of this process is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: The most common complication is Intercosto-Brachial nerve injury

options.label: B
options.text: The most common cause of Secondary Lymphedema is LN Dissection

options.label: D
options.text: The most common sentinel nodes are LEVEL 1 Axillary LN

questions.correct_answer: A. The most common complication is Intercosto-Brachial nerve injury
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The most common complication is Intercosto-Brachial nerve injury Seromas beneath the skin flaps or in the axilla represent the most frequent complication of mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection. In developed countries, the most common cause of secondary lymphedema is resection or ablation of regional lymph nodes by surgery. Lymphangiosarcoma , or Stewart Treves syndrome , is a rare tumour that develops as a complication of long-standing (usually more than 10 years) lymphedema The most common complication of Modified Radical Mastectomy is seroma , not ICBN injury.

Highyeild:

Stewart-Treves Syndrome Stewart-Treves Syndrome: is lymphangiosarcoma of the upper extremity in women who have undergone radical mastectomy and have ipsilateral lymphedema. On average, the interval between mastectomy and the development of angiosarcoma is around 10.5 years. In 60% of women , the development of this cancer is associated with a history of adjuvant radiation therapy. Clinical features include acute worsening of edema, and the appearance of subcutaneous nodules with a tendency towards haemorrhage and ulceration. The treatment approach involves preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision, typically with a radical amputation. This condition is associated with a poor prognosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. The most common cause of secondary lymphedema is the resection or ablation of regional lymph nodes by surgery. Option: C. Long-standing Lymphedema causes Stewart Treves Syndrome , Lymphangiosarcoma , which is a rare tumour that develops as a complication of long-standing Lymphedema. Option: D. Most common sentinel nodes are LEVEL 1 Axillary LN.

questions.text: A patient with Breast Cancer is Planned for Surgery after Neoadjuvant chemotherapy, for locally advanced disease. Which of the following structures is not preserved in this surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pectoralis Fascia The Surgery done for locally advanced Breast Cancer after Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is MODIFIED RADICAL MASTECTOMY. Pectoral fascia is elevated off the underlying musculature, which allows for the complete removal of the breast. Structures removed in PATEY MRM: The whole breast; A large portion of skin, the centre of which overlies the tumour but which always includes the nipple; All of the fat, fascia and lymph nodes of the axilla. The pectoralis minor muscle is either divided or retracted to gain access to the upper two-thirds of the axilla. A modified radical mastectomy permits the preservation of the Medial pectoral nerve & Lateral Pectoral nerve.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Pectoralis Major is preserved in MRM Option: C. Lateral Pectoral Nerve is preserved in MRM Option: D. Medial Pectoral Nerve is preserved in MRM

questions.text: Match the following breast surgeries to their processes. MRM-MODIFIED RADICAL MASTECTOMY RM-RADICAL MASTECTOMY(Halstead) SM-SIMPLE MASTECTOMY BCS-BREAST CONSERVING SURGERY
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-MRM, 2-BCS, 3-SM, 4-RM Surgical Options for breasts have evolved and there has been a gradual shift towards more conservative techniques: Radical Halsted Mastectomy Modified Radical Mastectomy Statement 1 . Modified Radical Mastectomy which includes excision of the whole breast, a large portion of skin, the nipple, all of the fat, fascia and lymph nodes of the axilla. The pectoralis minor muscle is either divided or retracted to gain access to the upper two-thirds of the axilla. Statement 2 . The Radical Halsted Mastectomy includes excision of the breast, nipple-areola complex, axillary lymph nodes and pectoralis major and minor muscles. It is not done nowadays. Statement 3 . Simple mastectomy involves the removal of only the breast with no dissection of the axilla. LN dissection is not a concern here. Statement 4 . Breast-Conserving Surgery involves the removal of the only tumour plus a margin of normal breast tissue. These operations are usually combined with axillary surgery, usually via a separate incision in the axilla. Sentinel LN Biopsy, & removal of Level 2, or Level 3 LN is also done.
